The proposed regulation is inconsistent with current statutes, regulations, and prior ATF opinion letters regarding the definition and application of the term Machine Gun as defined in 26 U.S. Code 5845(b) and 27 CFR 479.11.

Categorization as a machine gun requires the item to be: "Any weapon which shoots, is designed to shoot, or can be readily restored to shoot,automatically more than one shot, without manual reloading, by a single function of the trigger. The term shall also include ... any part designed and intended solely and exclusively, or combination of parts designed and intended, for use in converting a weapon into a machine gun...."
Bump stock type devices do not meet the definition of machine gun. Installation and use of a bump stock type device does not permit the firearm to fire automatically more than one shot, without manual reloading, by a single function of the trigger. A single function of the trigger is required in order to fire a single shot, without manual reloading, and two additional functions of the trigger are required in order to fire a subsequent shot. Both a release and subsequent pull of the trigger are required before the next round can be fired from the firearm.

Additionally, ATF has previously opined on the categorization of of bump stock type devices. Re-categorization and/or redefinition of regulations to allow for bump stock type devices to meet the definition of Machine Gun would undermine a long line of previously understood regulations with unknown ripple effects. The matter at hand is not simply agency deference, but such sweeping considerations need come from the Legislative Branch.

To whom it may concern,

Thank you for taking the time to review all of our comments. I realize that this is a time consuming process, and I appreciate you spending the time to listen to input from everyone.
Regarding the proposition to reclassify "bump stock" devices as machine guns, I respectfully disagree. This would amount to banning a device that does nothing to change the way a firearm operates. A semi-automatic firearm can be "bump fired" with or without a "bump stock." The "bump stock" merely provides one of many methods of doing so. I'm sure you are aware that semi-automatic firearms can be "bump fired" in many ways (such as with a piece of string, or even just be holding the rifle in the proper manner without any extra equipment). The act of "bump firing" is merely a method of rapidly depressing the trigger, and does nothing to change the functioning mechanism of the firearm. The bump stocks still require the shooter to push forward on the firearm for each successive shot to manually reset the trigger. Without this forward pressure, the bump stock in itself will not allow a single discharge of ammunition, no matter how long the trigger is depressed. In essence, the shooter is pulling the entire firearm forward, while holding the trigger in place, rather than depressing the trigger while the firearm remains in place. Consequently, the banning of "bump stocks" would in no way prevent "bump firing," and could lead to murky circumstances wherein shoelaces, belt loops, or even ones hand are considered bump stock devices! Conversely, banning these devices already in production or in circulation would put an unnecessary burden on those manufacturers that have invested a great deal time and money in setting up production capability, as well as retailers and consumers that have elected to purchase these devices.

Regarding the terrible event in Las Vegas, It seems that, while this event was a terrible tragedy, the banning of "bump stock" devices would have done nothing to have affected the outcome. Had the perpetrator been unable to procure a slide-fire bump stock, he could have "bump fired" his firearm in a number of other ways. "Bump firing" a firearm is not an accurate firing method. It seems that the main reason the shooter was able to inflict so much damage, was because he was shooting into a mass of thousands of people. He did not have to be accurate to inflict damage because there were so many people in close proximity. His firing method did not matter as much as the amount of time he was able to fire unrestricted into the crowd. Additionally, a man as wealthy as the shooter, would have been able to procure a "bump stock" if he wanted to on the black market, ban or no ban, as he obviously had no regard for the law.

In conclusion, banning "bump stocks" will be ineffectual in stopping any individual from "bump firing" a firearm, and even if a ban would have kept the Las Vegas shooter from procurring one, it would not have prevented the damage that he inflicted on the crowd.

Thank you for taking the time to review my comments,
Joe Marra

This rule for Proposed Information Collection on Application for Non-immigrant Visa must be rejected in part requiring additional social media and other electronic information collection for the following reasons:

1. No reasonable attempt has been made to justify adding social media identifiers, e-mails and other volatile data to the list of required information. There is no way for the consular officer to verify that the information provided is complete or accurate, beyond what can be derived from other identifiers, i.e. name, DOB etc., so there is no additional value provided by attempting to collect this information. List of social media platforms is not specified in the Proposal, but it must be noted that people in different countries tend to use local social media platforms, and there is no way all those local platforms can be included in mentioned list without making it so large that it cannot be processed in reasonable time. More than that, new platforms are emerging and gaining popularity quickly and unpredictably, and proposed list is bound to become irrelevant pretty quickly.

2. No estimate is provided of how expensive any good faith implementation of this requirement may be. However, some estimates can be done quite easily. The number of visas issued every year is between 10 and 15 million. Even if we do not count rejected applications, this is quite a lot. Let's say average number of electronic accounts provided by an applicant is 3. Let's (very) optimistically presume that consular officer can evaluate each account in about 20 minutes. That means about 1 additional person/hour will be spent by consular service or its contractors on each application. That means additional 10 - 15 million hours at the rate of at least$40/hour, so about $500 million additional spending will be required. That is 5 times more than the total Visa Services budget allocated for 2017 budget year. So proposed regulation is expensive, even though the benefits are not even remotely clear.

3. Countries tend to use the principle of reciprocity in visa matters, so it is reasonable to expect that other countries will impose similar requirements on US citizens seeking entry. That means that additional burden will be placed by this ill conceived regulation on US citizens travelling abroad, again, with no clear benefits in sight. More than that, it may even hurt our security by making US citizens' e-mails and other data easily identifiable and accessible for foreign actors.

4. People may and do consider their social media accounts and e-mails to be their private business. Initial response to media reports on this proposed regulation shows that it does not make us any friends and have the potential to reduce the number of people travelling to US on visas, thus hurting tourism, free exchange of cultures and ideas. It may offend many good people who is rightly considering it as another act in security theater of absurd, but in no way prevent "bad dudes" from hiding the information they do not want to disclose and entering the US. Instead of these intrusive and senseless questions, why just not add another checkbox to the form: "Are you planning to hurt US citizens or interests, Yes/No" and reject everyone who answers "Yes"? That would be much shorter, cheaper and make more sense.

Respectfully,
Proud to be an American

The issue of protecting the genetic integrity of seed grown on organic land is related to two others that are not on the agenda -strengthening and clarifying the requirements for the use of organic seed, and excluded methods terminology. Addressing these two issues adequately would help to ensure that the presence of plants growing from GE seeds is greatly reduced on organic farms.

The issue of protecting the genetic integrity of seed grown on organic land is concerned with those instances when organic producers plant nonorganic seed, so any efforts to strengthen the requirements for organic seed would tend to eliminate the problem. Strengthening and clarifying the requirements for the use of organic seed should remain on the agenda to eliminate inconsistencies in the enforcement of the National Organic Program's (NOP's) broad exemption that allows the use of conventionally produced seed in certified organic. A rule change to the seed practice standard is needed to require a demonstrable improvement over time until 100% organic seed use is achieved.

Excluded methods terminology should be maintained on the NOSB agenda to keep up with a fast-moving biotechnology industry. Organic regulations prohibit the use of genetic engineering, but the NOP needs to define terms in order to ensure that those regulations are enforceable.
Efforts to quantify the extent of GE contamination and provide transparency in GE content of non-organic seeds should not further burden organic growers.

It is important for the NOSB to maintain a focus on the problem of contaminated inputs, which threatens the quality of organic products and soil on organic farms. However, the NOSB last addressed the issue in a report in Spring 2015. The report offered an approach for addressing this complex issue through examining feedstocks and pathways. We support the approach in that report. In the intervening three years, the NOSB has not made progress, but another source of contamination has risen in importance use of water contaminated by oil and gas production. If "organic" is to maintain its meaning, we must prevent the unintended contamination that can occur when organic matter is recycled from off-farm sources, or when outside forces contaminate water supplies.

"Inert" ingredients frequently comprise as much as 99% of pesticide products. So-called "inert" ingredients are not inert, and are not disclosed to users or others who may be exposed. Given NOSB scrutiny of active ingredients, "inert" ingredients may be the most hazardous ingredients in pesticide products used in organic production. We urge the NOSB to insist that NOP move forward quickly with implementation of the NOSB recommendations on "inert" ingredients. Allowing the current lack of movement to persist raises serious compliance issues and threatens the integrity of the USDA organic label.

April 2, 2018

Ms. Sasha Gersten-Paal
SNAP Program Development Division

3101 Park Center Drive, Rm 812

Dear Ms. Gersten-Paal:

Arizona Community Action Association (ACAA) is a statewide organization that advocates for fair practices and policies, with the goal of stopping poverty before it starts. Our organization understands the critical role that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) plays in addressing hunger and food insecurity in our community, and we pay close attention to any potential changes to SNAP.

SNAP helps 900,000 Arizonans put food on the table each month. If a time limit for able-bodied adults without dependents (ABAWDs) to receive nutrition assistance was applied statewide (without state discretion), an estimated 25,000 low-income individuals in our state would lose their access to food and nutritionat a time when they need it most.

In thirteen of Arizona's fifteen counties, individuals earning minimum wage are not earning a living wage. Even if a person works full-time at the minimum wage rate of $10.50 per hour, the cost of living is too high to afford the most basic needs, such as food, health care, and rent on a one-bedroom apartment. In Maricopa County, for example, individuals would need to earn $15.67 per hour in order to afford these basic essentials. In Coconino County, they would need to earn $17.69 per hour - a full $7.19 more than our current minimum wage. The living wage calculation is based on Fair Market Rent data from the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Importantly, this calculation does not account for additional costs that many people incur, such as the cost of childcare.

SNAP provides working low-income individuals and families with nutritious food when they might otherwise go hungry.
First and foremost, SNAP is a nutrition program. As such, it has been proven to contribute to a wide range of improved health outcomes, increased learning capacity in children, and reduced healthcare costs. In ACAA's role as Arizona's SNAP Community Outreach grantee, we see the important benefits that come from participation in SNAP. Participating in SNAP is critical to efforts to improve the diet and health of low-income households, and we urge USDA to find ways to keep this vulnerable population connected to basic food assistance.

In Arizona, the unemployment rate remains high in many of our counties, especially Apache, Navajo, and Yuma. As a result, Governor Doug Ducey has kept "ABAWD waivers" in place in 12 of our 15 counties (meaning the time limits are not imposed in these counties). We support this decision to NOT deny someone's access to food by requiring them to find work in areas where sufficient, suitable jobs do not exist. We ask that the USDA maintain states' discretion over when and where to apply for a waiver because expanding the harsh SNAP time limit for childless adults will reduce food security, shift the burden of food assistance to local charities, and undermine health in Arizona's families.

ACAA believes the current ABAWD waiver rules are reasonable, transparent, and manageable for states to operationalize. Any change that would restrict, impede, or add uncertainty to our state's ability to waive areas with elevated unemployment must not be pursued.

While we don't support harsh work requirements, as an organization focused on healthy communities, we do understand and uphold the value of work. We recognize that Arizona's Department of Economic Security (DES), which administers SNAP and SNAP E&T, has seen a considerable increase in job placements and retention among SNAP participants over the past year. But we still have a long way to go before the network of providers expands and improves enough to absorb the additional caseload.

The only action we encourage USDA to take with respect to this time limit rule is to propose its elimination. Restoring SNAP's ability to provide food assistance to impoverished, unemployed people would be a powerful policy improvement that would reduce food insecurity among those seeking work.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on USDA's Advanced Notice on requirements and services for able-bodied adults without dependents.

Sincerely,

Cynthia Zwick
Executive Director
Arizona Community Action Association

The newly proposed interpretation of the definition of a machinegun (26 USC 5845(b)) to include a "bump-stock" device is not consistent with the obvious meaning of the definition of machinegun, as well as ATF's previous decision on "bump-stock" devices not meeting the definition of a machinegun.

The ATF FTB 2010 letter (attached) contained the following:
"The stock has no automatically functioning mechanical parts or springs and performs no automatic mechanical function when installed. In order to use the install device, the shooter must apply constant forward pressure with the non-shooting hand and the constant rearward pressure with the shooting hand. Accordingly, we find that the "bump-stock" is a firearm part and is not regulated as a firearm under Gun Control Act or the National Firearms Act."

In order to meet the definition of machinegun, "more than one shot" has to be fired "by a single function of the trigger". Although the "bump-stock" device allows you to fire a rifle in an unconventional manner, i.e. pulling the trigger into the shooter's trigger finger versus pulling the trigger back with the trigger finger, only one shot is fired per function of the trigger.

The AG's letter implies that once the initial trigger pull is completed by pulling the trigger forward into the stationary trigger finger, that the rifle will just continue to automatically fire. This is not correct. As specifically mentioned in the 2010 ATF FTB letter, a "constant forward pressure" must be applied with the non-firing hand so that the trigger can continue to be pulled, i.e. functioned, once for every single shot fired. If the forward pressure is stopped, firing stops. In order to classify "bump-stocks" as machineguns, the AG's interpretation would require that the term "trigger" be removed from the definition of a machinegun and replaced with "fore-end" or "forward grip" or "any part of the rifle". A trigger is a trigger, and the definition of a machinegun says function of the trigger, not "fore-end" or "forward grip" or "any part of the rifle".

In conclusion, this new DOJ interpretation (proposed rule) stretches the definition of a machinegun too far in an attempt to encompass the function of a "bump-stock". The proposed rule fails to show that a "bump-stock" device is a machinegun per the definition of a machinegun, both in obvious meaning and in technical definition.

Not only should this proposed rule change not be implemented because it is legally incorrect, but due to the fact that it is so obviously incorrect it is sure to face legal challenges and will most likely be defeated in court. After all, even the ATF FTB said in writing that a "bump-stock" device is not a machinegun. That is an obvious waste of time, resources and tax payer money.

To remove these valuable products from organic use would be devastating to organic farming.
